title: Eccl 1:1
text:
1:1 Preacher. The Hebrew emphasizes Solomon’s function as convener of the covenant community to witness and to celebrate the glory of the King of heaven that fills His earthly temple (1 Kin. 8). Solomon’s words are directed to God’s people, not to agnostics.

son of David. See Introduction: Author.

title: Eccl 1:2
text:
1:2 Vanity. The Hebrew word means “breath” or “vapor,” and hence what is “insubstantial,” “useless,” or “futile.” Human death makes the deeds and desires of people who build earthly culture (“under the sun”) useless.

All. This word is qualified by the phrase “under the sun” (v. 3) and means everything people experience with their senses (v. 8).

title: Eccl 1:3–11
text: 1:3–11 The phrase, “What does man gain,” provides the theme of this opening poem, focusing the reader’s attention on the apparent futility of work and study. Although these offer some satisfaction in accomplishment, death seems to make them meaningless.

title: Eccl 1:3–8
text: 1:3–8 Because of death, people must continuously begin cultural labors again. They are never completely satisfied with the results and are driven to repeat previous efforts.

title: Eccl 1:3
text:
1:3 gain. The idea that life’s labor is unprofitable, presented here as a rhetorical question, is stated directly in 2:11.

under the sun. This phrase is synonymous with “under heaven” and “on earth.” Paul’s equivalent is “the present evil age” (Gal. 1:4). The energies poured into earthly kingdoms are often of no value to the kingdom of heaven (Mark 8:36). By contrast, the work of the Lord is not in vain (John 6:27–29; 1 Cor. 15:58).

title: Eccl 1:4
text: 1:4 goes . . . comes. People are constantly starting over (like the sun in v. 5), while by contrast the earth (to which every person returns) abides.

title: Eccl 1:6
text: 1:6 around and around. This phrase is the focal point of the poem in 1:4–8, an image for Solomon’s recurrent refrain “striving after wind.”

title: Eccl 1:7
text: 1:7 is not full. People’s experiences commonly never fill or satisfy them, just as waters never fill the sea.

title: Eccl 1:9–11
text: 1:9–11 Cultural endeavors cannot reverse the futile process of repeating what has already been done, for all die and their works are forgotten.

title: Eccl 1:12–15
text: 1:12–15 Solomon’s personal investigation concludes that human culture is misdirected and incomplete.

title: Eccl 1:12
text: 1:12 king . . . in Jerusalem. See Introduction: Author.

title: Eccl 1:13
text:
1:13 by wisdom. The endeavors of this world performed under the curse of God (Gen. 3:16–19) are futile and frustrating.

unhappy business. Human existence includes divinely imposed burdens (Gen. 3:16–19; Rom. 8:22, 23). Jesus makes them bearable (Matt. 11:28–30).

God. God’s personal covenant name “Yahweh” (conventionally translated Lord, with small capitals) is not used in this book.

title: Eccl 1:13–14
text: 1:13, 14 under heaven . . . under the sun. See 1:3 note.

title: Eccl 1:14
text: 1:14 I have seen everything. Solomon had an accurate perspective on the present, because of God’s gift (1 Kin. 3), as well as on the past, because he meditated on God’s revealed Word.

title: Eccl 1:15
text: 1:15 crooked . . . lacking. This is the result not only of human evil, but also of the divine curse (7:13; Gen. 3:16–19).

title: Eccl 1:16
text:
1:16 wisdom. An increase in true wisdom heightens one’s sensitivity to the unhappy effects of sin, not all of which are immediately visible.

all who were over Jerusalem. From Solomon’s perspective these would refer to ancient pre-Israelite kings (Gen. 14:18; Josh. 10:1).

title: Eccl 2:1–11
text: 2:1–11 The joys of earthly accomplishments are unsatisfying, for Solomon in particular (1 Kin. 4–11).

title: Eccl 2:1
text: 2:1 pleasure. A reference to self-indulgence.

title: Eccl 2:3
text: 2:3 my heart still guiding me. See v. 9. To determine what was good for people to do, Solomon investigated life without forgetting the protective guidance of God’s word.

title: Eccl 2:4–9
text: 2:4–9 great . . . surpassed. The world’s wealth flowed into Jerusalem for Solomon’s disposition.

title: Eccl 2:10–11
text: 2:10, 11 found pleasure . . . reward . . . under the sun. Solomon experienced joy in doing work, but failed to achieve the satisfaction of producing anything of final heavenly value.

title: Eccl 2:12–17
text: 2:12–17 The earthly advantage of wisdom over folly is canceled by death.

title: Eccl 2:12–13
text: 2:12, 13 wisdom. Not secular wisdom or shrewdness, but unmatched, God-given wisdom.

title: Eccl 2:15
text: 2:15 wise. Wisdom’s value appears to be compromised because it cannot keep the wise any more than the fool from the abyss of death.

title: Eccl 2:17
text: 2:17 hated. Concluding that the curse of death erases the profit of wise labor, Solomon comes to hate life in this present evil age.

title: Eccl 2:18–26
text: 2:18–26 Solomon reflects on the frustrations associated with work. Death takes labor’s profit from its producer. The situation is made harder to bear by not knowing whether in the future the property will be dissipated by a fool (vv. 18, 19) or given to an heir who will not appreciate it (vv. 20, 21).

title: Eccl 2:23
text: 2:23 does not rest. The ever-present, painful burdens of life undermine even the legitimate pleasures of work (v. 10) and can deprive the laborer of sleep.

title: Eccl 2:24
text: 2:24 better. In his conclusion about what is good (v. 3) Solomon observes that the common pleasures of life and work are also from God.

title: Eccl 2:26
text:
2:26 to the one who pleases him . . . sinner. However great the temporary prosperity of the wicked, it is the righteous “who please God” who are at last the beneficiaries of God’s blessings.

vanity. The point seems to be the futility of the work of one person being transferred to another, as in vv. 20, 21.

title: Eccl 3:1
text: 3:1 time. The truly wise know that all their “times” are in God’s hand (Ps. 31:15) and that there is an appropriate time for every human activity.

title: Eccl 3:11
text: 3:11 eternity. This is the Hebrew term translated “forever” in v. 14 and explained in v. 11 as “from the beginning to the end.” The heart knows that history is not meaningless, but is frustrated in its efforts to discern the pattern of events.

title: Eccl 3:12
text: 3:12 nothing better. The author’s major application is his repeated advice (2:24–26; 3:12, 22; 5:18–20; 8:15) and command (9:7–10) to be content with what God has ordained for one’s life (1 Cor. 7:20; 1 Tim. 6:8).

title: Eccl 3:14
text: 3:14 fear. The term means to give God the honor corresponding to what He is (Ex. 34:8; Is. 6:5; Luke 5:8; Rev. 1:17).

title: Eccl 3:15–21
text: 3:15–21 God the Judge is in view.

title: Eccl 3:17
text:
3:17 the righteous and the wicked. As punishment for sin, people, like animals (vv. 18–20), must die (Gen. 3:19). Nevertheless the distinction between the righteous and the wicked is not removed by death, but will be revealed at God’s judgment.

time. God ordains whatever occurs on earth (vv. 1–8). He has also appointed a day for judging the deeds of all (the “day of the Lord”; Joel 3).

title: Eccl 3:21
text: 3:21 Who knows whether the spirit of man. Elsewhere Solomon observes that though the physical body returns to dust, the spirit returns to God (12:7).

title: Eccl 4:1–3
text: 4:1–3 the oppressions . . . more fortunate. Viewing the plight of the oppressed, Solomon speculates that the dead and unborn are better off.

title: Eccl 4:4–16
text: 4:4–16 Envy and lack of contentment fuel the futile drive for earthly satisfaction.

title: Eccl 4:5–6
text: 4:5, 6 quietness. Notwithstanding his previous dark thoughts, Solomon does conclude that sufficiency with contentment is better than need resulting from laziness (v. 5) or excess accompanied by restless toil (vv. 6, 8).

title: Eccl 4:9–12
text: 4:9–12 Two. Cooperation, rather than strife rooted in envy, produces success and provides protection from the covetous.

title: Eccl 4:13–16
text: 4:13–16 A characteristically discontented people does not appreciate good leaders, a thought that brings Solomon back to his theme of the apparent futility of life.

title: Eccl 5:1–7
text: 5:1–7 The summary of the book (12:13) enlarges on the exhortation to fear God (v. 7), the principle here emphasized by Solomon.

title: Eccl 5:2
text: 5:2 mouth. The thoughts of the heart are expressed in the words of the mouth. God will judge them (Matt. 12:34–37).

title: Eccl 5:4–5
text: 5:4, 5 vow. A particular promise made to God (Deut. 23:21–23). See “Honest Speech, Oaths, and Vows” at Neh. 5:12.

title: Eccl 5:6
text:
5:6 mouth. See note on v. 2.

messenger. This Hebrew word can also be translated “angel.” It could refer to a priest serving in the temple (Mal. 2:7).

title: Eccl 5:8–17
text: 5:8–17 Greed is responsible for many of the detrimental aspects of wealth.

title: Eccl 5:8
text: 5:8 do not be amazed. Oppression and injustice are inevitable (4:1–3).

title: Eccl 5:10–12
text: 5:10–12 loves money. Greed is insatiable and robs one of sleep; contentment provides rest (1 Tim. 6:6–10).

title: Eccl 5:13–17
text: 5:13–17 Solomon ponders the tragedies of unused and lost wealth. Whatever is not lost “in a bad venture” must be left behind at death. Earthly labor appears to be in vain.

title: Eccl 5:18–6:7
text: 5:18–6:7 God sovereignly distributes wealth.

title: Eccl 5:18
text: 5:18 good. God intends that people should enjoy the benefits of their work as a due reward of their labor.

title: Eccl 5:19
text: 5:19 gift of God. The ability to enjoy earthly labor comes not from stoic human strength, but from God-given grace, granted to rich and poor (v. 12) alike.

title: Eccl 6:2
text:
6:2 God. Riches and poverty, as well as the ability or inability to enjoy one’s resources, are decreed by God.

power to enjoy. This involves control over the management of wealth, not merely pleasure derived from spending it.

title: Eccl 6:3
text: 6:3 his soul is not satisfied with life’s good things. To be discontented with God’s abundant provision is a great tragedy.

title: Eccl 6:6
text: 6:6 one place. The case of those who live long in discontent is more pathetic than that of a stillborn child. The stillborn, at least, does not spend long years in the self-inflicted misery of ingratitude.

title: Eccl 6:7
text: 6:7 appetite is not satisfied. Again, earthly labor by itself does not fill the emptiness of the soul (1:8).

title: Eccl 6:8
text: 6:8 what does the poor man have. Those, though poor, who know how to live effectively in the world avoid the discontentment of wandering, unsatisfied desires.

title: Eccl 6:10
text:
6:10 named . . . known. God identifies every person as a sinner (7:20).

dispute. No one, apart from Christ, has a defense against God.

title: Eccl 7:1
text: 7:1 day of death. For the godly, death is “far better” (Phil. 1:23) because they are with Christ.

title: Eccl 7:2, 4
text: 7:2, 4 house of mourning. A funeral provides an indispensable perspective on the universally terminal condition.

title: Eccl 7:7
text: 7:7 oppression . . . a bribe. These common experiences may threaten to destabilize an otherwise good spiritual condition (4:1–3).

title: Eccl 7:9
text: 7:9 anger lodges. If unquenched, the anger ignited by life’s frustrations leads to folly.

title: Eccl 7:11–12
text: 7:11, 12 Wisdom . . . preserves the life. True wisdom gives benefits in this life (contrast 8:8) and that to come. Christ is the redemptive wisdom of God (1 Cor. 1:30), making wisdom accessible to sinners.

title: Eccl 7:13–18
text: 7:13–18 Both human illusions of perfection in this life and the abandonment of oneself to wickedness have God for an adversary.

title: Eccl 7:13
text: 7:13 who can make straight. God’s decrees cannot be reversed. The curse of Gen. 3 will not be annulled until the consummation.

title: Eccl 7:14
text:
7:14 prosperity . . . adversity. God decrees the one as the other.

man may not find out anything. The future is unknown.

title: Eccl 7:15
text: 7:15 righteous . . . wicked. The question implied by this observation is formulated in Jer. 12:1 (“Why does the way of the wicked prosper?”) and handled at more length in Ps. 37 and 73.

title: Eccl 7:16–17
text: 7:16, 17 Be not overly righteous . . . overly wicked. Pride can masquerade as righteousness, even in small things; on the other hand, there is an impulse to lawlessness that goes beyond everyday standards of life.

title: Eccl 7:18
text: 7:18 this . . . from that. Right knowledge of God delivers those who possess it from destructive excesses of self-righteousness and wickedness.

title: Eccl 7:19
text: 7:19 gives strength to the wise. Wisdom is powerful and encouraging.

title: Eccl 7:20
text: 7:20 not a righteous man. All are guilty before God (Ps. 14:3; 53:3).

title: Eccl 7:22
text: 7:22 many times. We are all multiple offenders in God’s sight.

title: Eccl 7:24
text: 7:24 who can find it out. No one can fully comprehend God’s understanding; it is qualitatively different from human knowledge (8:16, 17; 1 Cor. 2:11).

title: Eccl 7:29
text: 7:29 made man upright. God created Adam morally good (Gen. 1:31), but all sin (Rom. 3:23; 5:12). See “The Fall” at Gen. 3:6.

title: Eccl 8:5–6
text: 8:5, 6 proper time and the just way. The truly wise seek and commonly find the proper time for every action (3:1–8).

title: Eccl 8:8
text: 8:8 power. We cannot control death or evil, but Christ has this power (John 10:18; Rev. 1:18).

title: Eccl 8:9
text: 8:9 to his hurt. Probably this means to hurt the one ruled. Solomon has seen how the irresponsible use of God-given authority injures people (Rom. 13:3, 4).

title: Eccl 8:10–13
text: 8:10–13 Though inequities abound in human societies, as experienced in civil disorders of our own time, God will nevertheless settle all accounts justly.

title: Eccl 8:14
text: 8:14 on earth. In this life the righteous and wicked do not necessarily get what they deserve.

title: Eccl 8:15
text: 8:15 commend. In the face of injustice, people are nevertheless to rejoice in this life. Solomon’s mode of expression is pessimistic, but in the immediate context he mentions that life is the gift of God.

title: Eccl 8:17
text:
8:17 all the work of God. See 7:13; 11:5.

cannot find out. God’s work cannot be fathomed.

title: Eccl 9:1–10
text: 9:1–10 Solomon commands the enjoyment of life, despite the reality of death.

title: Eccl 9:1
text:
9:1 in the hand of God. God sovereignly controls the affairs of both the righteous and wicked.

love or hate. Presently both “good” and “bad” things happen to righteous and wicked people according to God’s inscrutable design (Matt. 5:44, 45; Luke 13:1–5).

title: Eccl 9:3
text: 9:3 full of evil. People are totally depraved, that is, corrupt in every aspect (Gen. 6:5).

title: Eccl 9:10
text: 9:10 with your might. Like v. 4, this verse emphasizes the necessity of dealing with life as we find it.

title: Eccl 9:11–12
text: 9:11, 12 chance. Solomon describes people as victims of inscrutable or even cruel chance. Nevertheless, the believer understands that God orders events in unexpected ways.

title: Eccl 9:16
text: 9:16 despised. Solomon sees that wisdom is indeed better than might—but that the wise are not appreciated.

title: Eccl 10:2
text: 10:2 right . . . left. These had the conventional meanings of good and bad, or blessing and cursing, in the ancient world.

title: Eccl 10:5
text: 10:5 error. Rulers often govern inappropriately.

title: Eccl 10:10
text: 10:10 sharpen the edge. Overcome the obstacles to effective work by being properly prepared with the wisdom or skill needed for the task.

title: Eccl 10:12–14
text: 10:12–14 words. Words reveal a person’s heart, and what is spoken can have serious consequences (Matt. 12:34–37).

title: Eccl 10:19
text: 10:19 everything. This can mean that money is needed for both food and wine, or that money provides life’s needs (cf. 7:12).

title: Eccl 10:20
text: 10:20 bird. A figure of speech meaning a spy or an informer.

title: Eccl 11:1
text: 11:1 bread upon the waters. Possibly a reference to Solomon’s grain trade by sea.

title: Eccl 11:2
text:
11:2 seven . . . eight. An admonition to spread the risks you take (v. 6).

you know not. Uncertainty is a reason for diversity in financial management. See v. 6.

title: Eccl 11:3–4
text: 11:3, 4 clouds. Do not use uncertainty as an excuse for laziness.

title: Eccl 11:5
text: 11:5 work of God. Here again is an affirmation of God’s incomprehensible, secret counsel (8:17 note).

title: Eccl 11:6
text: 11:6 do not know. See note on v. 2.

title: Eccl 11:7–12:7
text: 11:7–12:7 Natural, youthful life is to be governed with discretion, because this present life will be followed by a certain meeting with God (12:8).

title: Eccl 11:8
text: 11:8 rejoice . . . remember. The joys of present life should be held loosely, in the awareness that such joy is temporary.

title: Eccl 11:9
text: 11:9 judgment. Solomon does not encourage mindless self-indulgence, but gives a sober warning that God will bring everything into judgment (Matt. 12:36).

title: Eccl 12:1
text: 12:1 evil days. If pleasure is unrestrained in youth, both pleasure and the Creator will be unknown in later years.

title: Eccl 12:2–7
text: 12:2–7 Solomon comments on aging and death, using the extended metaphor of a house that is falling down. He contrasts the deterioration of the house with the permanence of nature. It is best to take the metaphors here for their overall effect, rather than speculate on the meaning of each individual figure. As the following notes indicate, some associations are clearer than others.

title: Eccl 12:3
text: 12:3 keepers of the house. The phrases here probably refer to parts of the body as members of a household.

title: Eccl 12:5
text:
12:5 the almond tree blossoms. Their white color is associated with the hair of the aged.

eternal home. The words refer not just to the grave, but to the presence of one’s Creator and Judge (v. 7).

title: Eccl 12:6
text: 12:6 golden bowl. These words describe a lamp broken in the fall caused by a break in a silver chain. Broken vessels and severed cords suggest the frailty that comes with aging.

title: Eccl 12:7
text: 12:7 the spirit returns. Human existence continues beyond death.

title: Eccl 12:8
text: 12:8 Vanity. A final reiteration of the Preacher’s refrain.

title: Eccl 12:9–14
text: 12:9–14 The book concludes with a tribute to Solomon’s wisdom, providing the keys to interpreting the book.

title: Eccl 12:11
text: 12:11 given by one Shepherd. The words of Ecclesiastes are God-breathed (2 Tim. 3:16).

title: Eccl 12:13
text: 12:13 end of the matter. Loyal submission to the rule of God is the central and summary admonition of wisdom literature (5:7; Job 28:28; Prov. 1:7; 9:10).

title: Eccl 12:14
text: 12:14 judgment. God’s judgment of thoughts and deeds is a dominant theme that emerges throughout the book (3:17; 8:12, 13; 11:9; 2 Cor. 5:10).
